title: 105_hr1481
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Restoration Act of 1998". Congress acknowledges the comprehensive Great Lakes Fishery Resources Restoration Study conducted in 1995, highlighting the need for additional actions and better coordination to protect and manage the fisheries in the Great Lakes Basin. The Great Lakes Basin requires recommended actions for managing its resources, including those that are currently unfunded but essential to meet goals. SEC. 3. REFERENCE; REPEAL. Each reference in this Act to the Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Restoration Act of 1990 is now referring to the Act enacted by title I of Public Law 101-537. The Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Restoration Act of 1990, enacted as title II of Public Law 101-646, is repealed. SEC. 4. PURPOSES.

Amends Section 1003 of the Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Restoration Act of 1990 to develop and implement proposals for the restoration of fish and wildlife resources in the Great Lakes Basin.

SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. Section 1004 of the Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Restoration Act of 1990 is amended to redefine certain paragraphs and terms, including the term 'Committee' as the Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Restoration Proposal Review Committee. The Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Restoration Act of 1990 is amended to redefine certain terms, including 'non-Federal source' and 'restoration'. The term 'Report' is defined as a specific document submitted in 1995. The Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Restoration Act of 1990 is amended to redefine certain terms. This includes adjustments to paragraphs (12) and (13) by removing unnecessary words and punctuation. SEC. 6. IDENTIFICATION, REVIEW, AND IMPLEMENTATION OF PROPOSALS. Amended Section 1005 of the Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Restoration Act of 1990 to focus on the process of identifying, reviewing, and implementing proposals. The Director, in consultation with the Committee, encourages the development and implementation of proposals for the restoration of fish and wildlife resources based on the results of the Report. State Directors and Indian tribes are requested to submit proposals in line with specific requirements and goals outlined in various agreements and plans related to Great Lakes conservation. The Great Lakes Fishery Commission retains authority for sea lamprey control and the establishment of a committee for reviewing fish and wildlife restoration proposals in the Great Lakes Basin. The Committee consists of representatives from State Directors and Indian tribes with Great Lakes fish and wildlife management authority in the Great Lakes Basin. State Directors and Tribal Chairs appoint their representatives, and the Great Lakes Coordinator of the US Fish and Wildlife Service participates as an observer. Members must recuse themselves from proposals they have submitted. The Committee reviews proposals annually to assess their effectiveness. The Committee, comprised of State Directors and Tribal Chairs, reviews proposals annually to assess their effectiveness and appropriateness in fulfilling the purposes of the title. The Director selects and funds proposals for implementation based on recommendations and goals specified in section 1006, considering the effectiveness in fulfilling the purposes of other applicable laws for restoration of the Great Lakes Basin fishery resources and habitat. Cost-sharing of at least 25% is required for implementing selected proposals. The Director selects and funds proposals for implementation based on recommendations and goals specified in section 1006. The cost of implementing selected proposals must be paid by non-Federal sources in cash or in-kind contributions. Federal funds received by a State or local government cannot be considered as a contribution by a non-Federal source. SEC. 7. REPORTS TO CONGRESS.

Section 1008 of the Great Lakes Fish and Wildlife Restoration Act of 1990 is amended to require the Director to submit a report to Congress detailing actions taken to solicit and review proposals, results of implemented proposals, and progress towards specified goals.

SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

Section 1009 of the Act is amended to address the authorization of appropriations. Authorization of appropriations for the Great Lakes Coordination Office and fish and wildlife restoration proposals is set at $3,500,000 and $4,500,000 respectively for fiscal years 1999 through 2004. No funds are to be used for administering the proposals.
